description: A traditional and highly nutritious dish made from the tender leaves of the cowpea plant. Eboo has a distinctive earthy, slightly bitter flavor and a mucilaginous (slightly slimy) texture when cooked, similar to okra. This texture is highly valued and helps to thicken the sauce, making it perfect for scooping with Ugali or Posho.

cultural_significance.cultural_notes: Eboo is a cherished traditional vegetable, especially among the Acholi, Langi, and Iteso people. It is often foraged from the wild or cultivated in home gardens. The vegetable is highly valued for its nutritional benefits and its ability to grow in semi-arid conditions. Cooking Eboo is a skill passed down through generations, and its unique texture is a beloved part of the culinary landscape in these regions. It represents resilience and the deep connection to local flora.

ingredients.name: Fresh Eboo (Cowpea) Leaves
ingredients.notes: About 8-10 cups, stripped from tough stems, washed thoroughly

ingredients.name: Traditional Soda Ash (Potassium Carbonate)
ingredients.notes: Optional, but traditional. It softens the leaves and enhances the mucilaginous texture.

ingredients.name: Groundnut Paste (Peanut Butter)
ingredients.notes: Optional, for a richer, creamier sauce

steps.instruction: Prepare the eboo leaves by stripping the tender leaves from the tough stems. Wash them thoroughly in several changes of water to remove all dirt and grit.
If using traditional soda ash (laro), dissolve the 1/2 teaspoon in 1 cup of water in the saucepan.
If NOT using soda ash, simply add 1 cup of plain water to the saucepan. Add the sliced onion and bring to a boil.
Add the washed eboo leaves to the boiling water. They will be voluminous but will quickly wilt down.
Cover the pot and let the leaves boil for about 10-15 minutes until they are very tender and have developed a characteristic mucilaginous (slightly slimy) texture.

cooking_indicators.visual: The leaves turn a dark green and the water becomes thick and slightly viscous.
cooking_indicators.texture: The leaves should be very soft.

steps.instruction: Add the chopped tomato and salt. If using groundnut paste, mix it with a little water first to form a smooth paste, then stir it into the pot.
Stir everything together and continue to simmer uncovered for another 5-7 minutes, allowing the flavors to meld and the sauce to thicken further. If it becomes too thick, add a little more water.
Taste and adjust the salt if needed. The dish should have a thick, cohesive sauce that coats the leaves.
Serve the eboo hot as a flavorful and nutritious side dish.

serving_suggestions: Eboo is traditionally served as a side dish with a staple carbohydrate to complement its texture. It is perfect with Posho (Ugali), Millet Bread (Kalo), or Cassava. The thick, mucilaginous sauce is ideal for scooping. It can also be served with sweet potatoes or boiled green bananas.
